title: HTTP 202 response raises an exception
body:
Zeep version 2.4.0.

If the server responds with HTTP 202 Accepted, Zeep sees that as an error, but that's not correct.

```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  [...]
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/site-packages/zeep/client.py", line 41, in __call__
    self._op_name, args, kwargs)
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/site-packages/zeep/wsdl/bindings/soap.py", line 121, in send
    return self.process_reply(client, operation_obj, response)
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/site-packages/zeep/wsdl/bindings/soap.py", line 138, in process_reply
    status_code=response.status_code)
zeep.exceptions.TransportError: Server returned HTTP status 202 (no content available)
```

FYI I'm getting this from WSO2 Identity Server.

title: When maxOccurs is > 1, the array assigned to the value ends up being a reference
body:
Zeep version: 1.4.1

Gist: https://gist.github.com/aerandir92/7a2310872fd95c4613e5819d881a22b7

When instantiating something through factory, it only returns a reference, resulting in broken experience when trying to create a the same type repeatedly. 

In the gist you see I use factory to create a new ArrayOfParticipant. I manipulate that object, then I try to create a second ArrayOfParticipant, but the resulting object is equal to the first one.

title: TypeError exception when calling service operation with a default attribute for parameter of type dateTime
body:
When calling a service operation that has a parameter of type `dateTime` with the default value set in the WSDL, the following exception is raised in:

https://github.com/mvantellingen/python-zeep/blob/master/src/zeep/xsd/types/builtins.py#L129

```
TypeError: combine() argument 1 must be datetime.date, not str
```

The WSDL definition (excerpt):

```xml
<s:element name="ItemList">
  <s:complexType>
    <s:sequence>
      <s:element minOccurs="0" maxOccurs="1" default="1899-12-30T00:00:00" name="DateFrom" type="s:dateTime"/>
      <s:element minOccurs="0" maxOccurs="1" default="1899-12-30T00:00:00" name="DateTo" type="s:dateTime"/>
    </s:sequence>
  </s:complexType>
</s:element>
```

Since the `accepted_types = (datetime.datetime,) + six.string_types` for `DateTime` a possible solution would be to simply return the value unchanged if it's of type `str` in:

https://github.com/mvantellingen/python-zeep/blob/master/src/zeep/xsd/types/builtins.py#L120

```python
class DateTime(BuiltinType, AnySimpleType):
    _default_qname = xsd_ns('dateTime')
    accepted_types = (datetime.datetime,) + six.string_types

    @check_no_collection
    def xmlvalue(self, value):

        if isinstance(value, str):
            return value

        # Bit of a hack, since datetime is a subclass of date we can't just
        # test it with an isinstance(). And actually, we should not really
        # care about the type, as long as it has the required attributes
        if not all(hasattr(value, attr) for attr in ('hour', 'minute', 'second')):
            value = datetime.datetime.combine(value, datetime.time(
                getattr(value, 'hour', 0),
                getattr(value, 'minute', 0),
                getattr(value, 'second', 0)))

        if getattr(value, 'microsecond', 0):
            return isodate.isostrf.strftime(value, '%Y-%m-%dT%H:%M:%S.%f%Z')
        return isodate.isostrf.strftime(value, '%Y-%m-%dT%H:%M:%S%Z')
```

title: TypeError: encode() argument 1 must be str, not None - if there is no charset in http-header
body:
Hi, Michael.
Thank you for this great zeep module. It seems the best for Python 3 at the moment.
Probably I can help you to make it better with this issue.

The problem is that if no charset was set in response http-header, type error will be raised.

This is a response from server (example)

------------------------
```
HTTP/1.1 200 OK
Server: nginx/1.11.5
Date: Tue, 14 Feb 2017 13:47:40 GMT
Content-Type: multipart/related; boundary="MIMEBoundary_ac7ef06563d301021317f66dde25efbee5a4bd174ac8b5d4"; type="application/xop+xml"; start="<0.9c7ef06563d301021317f66dde25efbee5a4bd174ac8b5d4@apache.org>"; start-info="text/xml"
Transfer-Encoding: chunked
Connection: keep-alive

--MIMEBoundary_ac7ef06563d301021317f66dde25efbee5a4bd174ac8b5d4
Content-Type: application/xop+xml; charset=UTF-8; type="text/xml"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: binary
Content-ID: <0.9c7ef06563d301021317f66dde25efbee5a4bd174ac8b5d4@apache.org>

<?xml version='1.0' encoding='UTF-8'?><soapenv:Envelope xmlns:soapenv="http://schemas.xmlsoap.org/soap/envelope/"><soapenv:Header/><soapenv:Body><ns:getFolderPathResponse xmlns:ns="http://somehost.org/xsd"><ns:return>/Folder</ns:return></ns:getFolderPathResponse></soapenv:Body></soapenv:Envelope>
--MIMEBoundary_ac7ef06563d301021317f66dde25efbee5a4bd174ac8b5d4--
```
------------------------



We see NO  charset=utf-8  here in header. W3c says that is normal (specs).
[trace.txt](https://github.com/mvantellingen/python-zeep/files/774814/trace.txt)



Because of that we have this error - 

```
/path/to/anaconda3/lib/python3.5/site-packages/requests_toolbelt/multipart/encoder.py in encode_with(string, encoding)
    408     """
    409     if not (string is None or isinstance(string, bytes)):
--> 410         return string.encode(encoding)
    411     return string
    412 
```

TypeError: encode() argument 1 must be str, not None 

It comes from transport object which use requests.response object filled with values from header.
response.encoding is None  when charset is omitted in http-header of response.

I went deep (using debugger) and then explored 'requests' module. It tries to guess in case charset is omitted in header but 'requests' module documentation says that we should set charset (encoding) directly (explicit) if we know it and utf-8 is a default for http/web.

Please let me know how I can set charset/encoding in transport object directly.

I'm not a python professional like you, I'm quite young in python so I apologise if this issue is not a problem at all.
Hopefully the problem not in my head. )))

With warm regards and respect to you as an author of this great zeep module.

1.
```
>>> zeep.__version__
'1.0.0'
```
2. As I see the problem is not in wsdl but I'm ready to provide it if you need.
3. An example script as well.
[Uploading trace.txt…]()

title: Failure on attempt to access services over HTTPS protocol.
body:
Hello, @mvantellingen! 

Congrats for this great Python SOAP client.

I've found an error related to the enhancement done for issue #228.

```
Failed to establish a new connection: [Errno -2] Name or service not known.
```

Take a look in `zeep.wsdl.bindings.soap.py` file, method `process_service_port` (lines 156-167).

```
def process_service_port(self, xmlelement, force_https=False):
    address_node = xmlelement.find('soap:address', namespaces=self.nsmap)

    # Force the usage of HTTPS when the force_https boolean is true
    location = address_node.get('location')
    if force_https and location and location.startswith('http://'):
        logger.warning("Forcing soap:address location to HTTPS")
        location = 'https://' + location[8:]

    return {
        'address': location
    }
```

`location[8:]` should be location[7:], cause it is a slice over 'http://' string. For example, if we have an address like `http://myserver.com/` the result will be `https://yserver.com/`.

I'm using  Zeep 0.22.1.

title: Missing items when parsing Choice
body:
- zeep 0.22
- [wsdl.zip](https://github.com/mvantellingen/python-zeep/files/591572/wsdl.zip)
- [script](https://gist.github.com/ri8on/38fcbcbd1edaac2977243b767f10d972)

response type looks like:
```
<xs:element name="getStateResult">
  <xs:complexType>
    <xs:complexContent>
      <xs:extension base="base:BaseAsyncResponseType">
        <xs:choice minOccurs="0">
          <xs:element ref="base:ErrorMessage"/>
          <xs:element name="NsiItem" type="nsi-base:NsiItemType"/>
          <xs:element name="NsiList" type="nsi-base:NsiListType"/>
        </xs:choice>
        <xs:attribute ref="base:version" use="required" fixed="10.0.1.2"/>
      </xs:extension>
    </xs:complexContent>
  </xs:complexType>
</xs:element>
```

`RequestState` and `MessageGUID` must be present, as defined in `BaseAsyncResponseType`, and one of `ErrorMessage`, `NsiItem` or `NsiList` can be present. However, only one (the first) element is in the output.

In the example the number of elements is limits here:
zeep.xsd.indicators.Choice#parse_xmlelements:
```
        if self.accepts_multiple:
            result = {name: result}
        else:
            result = result[0] if result else {}
```

Any ideas of the why and how ?

FYI, I temporarily solve this problem by modifying the following function in helpers.py:

```
def serialize_object(obj):
    """Serialize zeep objects to native python data structures"""
    if obj is None:
        return obj

    if isinstance(obj, list):
        return [serialize_object(sub) for sub in obj]

    result = OrderedDict()

    if(isinstance(obj, ET._Element)):
        def recursive_dict(element):
            return element.tag[element.tag.find('}')+1:], dict(map(recursive_dict, element)) or element.text
        return recursive_dict(obj)

    for key in obj:
        value = obj[key]
        if isinstance(value, (list, CompoundValue)):
            value = serialize_object(value)
        result[key] = value
    return result
```

title: ComplexType got an unexpected keyword argument
body:

WSDL: https://gist.github.com/moiseshiraldo/91f671f189788ceb31a2f8dc5a56b346

I can't provide you with the full WSDL since the service is private, but I've modified the response test to reproduce the error (please see my commit below). Let me know if something doesn't make sense.

The exception is raised [here](https://github.com/mvantellingen/python-zeep/blob/efeec29c934ef29c385766336d569fa2a491fafd/src/zeep/xsd/valueobjects.py#L158) because `available_kwargs` hasn't been cleared properly. I think the problem is in the `parse_kwargs` method of the `Choice` class:

```python
for i, choice in enumerate(self):
    temp_kwargs = copy.copy(available_kwargs)
    subresult = choice.parse_kwargs(kwargs, None, temp_kwargs)
    if subresult:
        if not found or not any(subresult.values()):
            available_kwargs.intersection_update(temp_kwargs)
        result.update(subresult)
        found = True
```

After that, the `temp_kwargs` is empty in my case, but `available_kwargs` still contains the name of the elements, thus throwing the exception later on. Maybe there's an `intersection_update` missing somewhere?

title: ArrayType serialization problem
body:
_Using: zeep==0.19.0_

Either I'm not using the Array properly, or something goes wrong when serializing it. I expect an array to be serialized as: `

``` xml
<values>
  <item>1</item>
  <item>2</item>
</values>
```

Instead, it's serialized as either the last element of a list, or (when nested) without the parent surrounded item element.

I added a test to the `test_wsdl_messages_rpc.py` to show the issue.

``` python
def test_serialize_wsdl_array_of_simple_types():
    wsdl_content = StringIO("""
    <definitions xmlns="http://schemas.xmlsoap.org/wsdl/"
        targetNamespace="http://tests.python-zeep.org/tns"
        xmlns:tns="http://tests.python-zeep.org/tns"
        xmlns:impl="http://tests.python-zeep.org/tns"
        xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"
        xmlns:wsdl="http://schemas.xmlsoap.org/wsdl/"
        xmlns:soap="http://schemas.xmlsoap.org/wsdl/soap/"
        xmlns:soapenc="http://schemas.xmlsoap.org/soap/encoding/">
      <types>
        <schema xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema" targetNamespace="http://tests.python-zeep.org/tns">
          <complexType name="ArrayOfString">
            <complexContent>
              <restriction base="soapenc:Array">
                <attribute ref="soapenc:arrayType" wsdl:arrayType="xsd:string[]"/>
              </restriction>
            </complexContent>
          </complexType>
        </schema>
      </types>
      <portType name="SimpleTypeArrayPortType">
        <operation name="getSimpleArray">
          <input message="tns:getSimpleArrayRequest"/>
          <output message="tns:getSimpleArrayResponse"/>
        </operation>
      </portType>
      <binding name="SimpleTypeArrayBinding" type="tns:SimpleTypeArrayPortType">
        <soap:binding style="rpc" transport="http://schemas.xmlsoap.org/soap/http"/>
        <operation name="getSimpleArray">
          <soap:operation soapAction=""/>
          <input>
            <soap:body use="encoded" namespace="http://tests.python-zeep.org/tns" encodingStyle="http://schemas.xmlsoap.org/soap/encoding/"/>
          </input>
          <output>
            <soap:body parts="return" use="encoded" namespace="http://tests.python-zeep.org/tns" encodingStyle="http://schemas.xmlsoap.org/soap/encoding/"/>
          </output>
        </operation>
      </binding>
      <message name="getSimpleArrayRequest">
        <part name="values" type="tns:ArrayOfString"/>
      </message>
      <message name="getSimpleArrayResponse"/>
    </definitions>
    """.strip())

    transport = DummyTransport()
    transport.bind(
        'http://schemas.xmlsoap.org/soap/encoding/',
        load_xml(io.open('tests/wsdl_files/soap-enc.xsd', 'r').read().encode('utf-8')))
    root = wsdl.Document(wsdl_content, transport)

    binding = root.bindings['{http://tests.python-zeep.org/tns}SimpleTypeArrayBinding']
    operation = binding.get('getSimpleArray')

    assert operation.input.signature() == 'values: ArrayOfString'

    ArrayOfString = root.types.get_type('ns0:ArrayOfString')
    val = ArrayOfString(['item', 'and', 'even', 'more', 'items'])

    serialized = operation.input.serialize(values=val)
    expected = """
        <?xml version="1.0"?>
        <soap-env:Envelope
            xmlns:ns0="http://tests.python-zeep.org/tns"
            xmlns:soap-env="http://schemas.xmlsoap.org/soap/envelope/">
          <soap-env:Body>
            <ns0:getSimpleArray>
              <values>
                <item>item</item>
                <item>and</item>
                <item>even</item>
                <item>more</item>
                <item>items</item>
              </values>
            </ns0:getSimpleArray>
          </soap-env:Body>
        </soap-env:Envelope>
    """
    assert_nodes_equal(expected, serialized.content)
```

Running the tests gave a few issues (see bottom), which led me to believe I am using the ArrayType incorrectly, but I don't see how else it should be used. 

The result is:

``` bash
E       assert '<soap-env:En...v:Envelope>\n' == '<soap-env:Env...v:Envelope>\n'
E         Skipping 171 identical leading characters in diff, use -v to show
E         +   <values>items</values>
E         -   <values>
E         -         <item>item</item>
E         -         <item>and</item>
E         -         <item>even</item>
E         -         <item>more</item>
E         -         <item>items</item>
E         -       </values>
E               </ns0:getSimpleArray>
E             </soap-env:Body>
E           </soap-env:Envelope>
```

So, why is the values element not a list of item-elements, but just the string of the last item element?

**Sidenote: Problems when running the above tests:**
`AttributeError: 'String' object has no attribute '_value_class'`
This bug is also mentioned #226, but the restriction checking makes sense. I changed it to:

_xsd/elements.py:137_

``` python
        if (
            self.restrict and not
            isinstance(value, (etree._Element, type(self.restrict)))

        ):
            raise TypeError((
                "Received object of type %r, " +
                "expected %s or etree.Element"
            ) % (type(value).__name__, type(self.restrict).__name__))
```

Then, the error would read: `TypeError: Received object of type 'str', expected String or etree.Element` which seems more correct but well, xsd.String and str probably result in the same thing.

For the test to continue, I simply removed that if-statement.

title: Action in Content-Type header and not SOAPAction. Soap 1.2.
Infinite recursion when parsing anyType element with xsi:nil="true"
body:
I stumbled onto this recently where when I received a response with this `<data xsi:type="xsd:anyType" xsi:nil="true"/>` in it, zeep would infinitely recur here `zeep/xsd/builtins.py", line 467, in parse_xmlelement`. Had to scrub the problematic xml but [this](https://gist.github.com/ryphill/4b4d9caec9033bd9c75bd3249f972f7b) should still trigger the problem.

I fixed it locally by making a slight modification to `AnyType`s `parse_xmlelement` method so it doesn't try to continuously reparse the anyType element if xsi:nil="true" but I'm not sure if that's the right solution.

``` python
def parse_xmlelement(self, xmlelement, schema=None, allow_none=True,
                         context=None):
        xsi_type = qname_attr(
            xmlelement,
            '{http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance}type')
        is_nil = (
            qname_attr(
                xmlelement,
                '{http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance}nil') == 'true')
        if xsi_type and schema and not is_nil:
            xsd_type = schema.get_type(xsi_type)
            return xsd_type.parse_xmlelement(
                xmlelement, schema, context=context)

        if xmlelement.text is None:
            return
        return self.pythonvalue(xmlelement.text)
```

title: NotImplementedError: parse_xmlelement not defined for UnionType
body:
I'm getting that error when `zeep` tries to parse an XML union element like this one: `<supplyDate>032002</supplyDate>`. This is the specification:

``` xml
<xs:simpleType name="Date">
    <xs:union memberTypes="xs:date xs:gYear xs:gYearMonth MMYY MMYYYY"/>
</xs:simpleType>
<xs:simpleType name="MMYY">
    <xs:restriction base="xs:string">
      <xs:pattern value="(0[123456789]|1[012]){1}\d{2}"/>
    </xs:restriction>
</xs:simpleType>
<xs:simpleType name="MMYYYY">
    <xs:restriction base="xs:string">
      <xs:pattern value="(0[123456789]|1[012]){1}\d{4}"/>
    </xs:restriction>
</xs:simpleType>
```

If I've understood properly what union types are, it means the field can be any of the supplied `memberTypes` and we have no simple way of knowing which one to parse. So I think the only workaround here is returning the `xmlelement.text` as it is. I've done that for the `UnionType` class and it's working fine in my case. If you agree that's an acceptable generic solution I can push the code and do a pull request.

Oh god, I hate SOAP. Thank you for your work making it less painful!

body:
I'm getting "NotImplementedError: QName.xmlvalue() not implemented" after this:

```
s = Client("WSDScannerService.wsdl")
svc = s.create_service("{http://schemas.microsoft.com/windows/2006/08/wdp/scan}ScannerServiceBinding", "http://10.0.4.105:8080/ScannerService/")
qnStatus=lxml.etree.QName("http://schemas.microsoft.com/windows/2006/08/wdp/scan", "ScannerStatus")
svc.GetScannerElements(s.get_element("ns0:GetScannerElementsRequest")(RequestedElements={"Name": qnStatus}))
```

The WSDL and XSDs are from http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/hardware/gg463146.aspx, the link titled "Scan Service Definition V1.0 for Web Services on Devices".

Even if I just do:

`svc.GetScannerElements(RequestedElements={"Name": "asd:qwe"})`

the result is the same.
zeep 0.17.0, lxml.etree 3.6.4, python 3.5.2 on 64bit Windows
Am I doing something wrong?
Thanks.

title: Element can only be used in _soapheaders once
body:
I have a service that takes authentication in a SOAP header. I can pass the authentication in zeep using the _soapheaders argument. However, if I pass the same value to two service calls, it doesn't work the second time. 

``` python
client = Client('https://api.example.com/?wsdl')
UserCredentials = client.get_element('{https://api.example.com/}UserCredentials')
header_value = UserCredentials(UserName='foo', Password='foo')

client.service.Foo(_soapheaders=[header_value])

client.service.Foo(_soapheaders=[header_value])
```

On the second call, zeep is sending a request with an empty `<UserCredentials/>` element. I expect it to use the same UserName and Password as the first request.

Additionally, it would be very useful if I could pass headers to the Client and have them automatically be used on every service call, instead of passing them every time.

title: LookupError: No type 'xxx' in namespace
body:
Using python-zeep 0.16. I am getting the error `LookupError: No type 'CountryItemType' in namespace http://schemas.xmlsoap.org/soap/encoding/`.

This is what I am doing (link to the WSDL in the code below):

``` python
from zeep import Client
from from zeep.transports import Transport
transport = Transport(http_auth=('***', '***'))
client = Client('http://www.visahq.com/wsdl.wsdl', transport=transport)
# Failing operation
client.service.doGetCountries()
```

If I check with `client.wsdl.dump()`, I can see this global type:
`ns0:CountryItemType(code: xsd:CountryCodeType, name: xsd:string)`

The failing operation is also defined there:
`doGetCountries() -> _value_1: CountryItemType[], arrayType: psd:string`

I verified at least one operation that is working, so it's not in the service itself. I tried also the master branch, but got the same results. Let me know if you need more information.

title: Fix handling of multiple message parts per operation
body:
I tried using this library for the first time today on a rather complex web service. It appears to not be reading the WSDL properly. This is the URL to the WSDL:

https://secure-wms.com/webserviceexternal/contracts.asmx?wsdl

When I run that through the Zeep WSDL examiner, I see that almost all of the services are showing exactly the same list of parameters, when in fact they should be quite different from each other. Zeep appears to be just taking the first parameter (which is a custom data type ns0:UserLoginData) and using that as the parameters for the service.

Is it just me? Or can you confirm this on your end as well.

title: Namespace prefixes ignored on SOAP responses.
body:
In certain implementations, the server will ignore the namespace prefixes used in the SOAP request, and use its own prefixes in the `xsi:type` tags of the response. This results in the response failing to parse because `zeep.xsd.Schema` stores its own prefix map and uses this when creating a QName (see `Schema._create_qname()`).

For example, in the following response XML:

```
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<SOAP-ENV:Envelope xmlns:SOAP-ENV="http://schemas.xmlsoap.org/soap/envelope/" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:SOAP-ENC="http://schemas.xmlsoap.org/soap/encoding/" xmlns:tns="http://api.radioreference.com/soap2">
    <SOAP-ENV:Body>
        <ns1:getTagResponse xmlns:ns1="http://api.radioreference.com/soap2">
            <return xsi:type="SOAP-ENC:Array" SOAP-ENC:arrayType="tns:tag[1]">
                <item xsi:type="tns:tag">
                    <tagId xsi:type="xsd:int">4</tagId>
                    <tagDescr xsi:type="xsd:string">EMS Dispatch</tagDescr>
                </item>
            </return>
        </ns1:getTagResponse>
    </SOAP-ENV:Body>
</SOAP-ENV:Envelope>
```

The exception is thrown: `ValueError: No namespace defined for the prefix 'tns'` because this namespace was defined as `ns0` by the Schema in `Schema._create_prefix_map()`.

title: can't get correct result from soap calling response
Handling None (Nil in XML)
body:
I have integrated a clunky wsdl (can't send as user/pw included in wsdl address) with SUDS and am trying to switch over to zeep - with one function call where I have to repeatedly poll a method to get up to 120,000 records zeep cut down the time from about 13-14 minutes using SUDS to 5 minutes using zeep - brilliant!

On another method though, where I have to set None for a lot of default values, zeep handles the XML parsing differently. Where SUDS puts these in the XML as for example, AccountType:
<ns0:AccountType xsi:nil="true"/>

Zeep puts the same default value as:
`<ns0:AccountType/>`

SUDS puts the same value as:
`<ns0:AccountType xsi:nil="true"/>`

It results in not getting any results back on this method via Zeep. Not sure if this is correct, but looking at this stack overflow answer, the way Zeep does this can be the equivalent of AccountType = '' rather than None/Null/Nil:
http://stackoverflow.com/questions/463597/what-does-inil-true-mean

Below are the SUDS and then Zeep XML for the same method call, where SUDS gets records back successfully but Zeep does not. Any thoughts? Great library by the way, so much faster than SUDS.

The nil/None/blank issue is affecting a number of parameters, and since the other method works without issues I suspect this is what is causing me not to get any results.

title: Parameters to service methods which are attributes on a complex type don't appear in soap request
body:
Hello, 

I'm making a service call with multiple parameters - some that map to elements and one that maps to an attribute on a complex type. Something like this:

```
zeepClient.service.<service method>(someparam='1', someattribute='2')
```

The resulting soap request includes `someparam` as expected but doesn't include `someattribute`. 

The Complex type associated w/ the request element looks something like the following:  

```
<xsd:complexType name="xyz">
    <xsd:sequence>
        <xsd:element name="someparam" type="xsd:string" minOccurs="0"/>
    </xsd:sequence>
    <xsd:attribute name="someattribute" type="xsd:string"/>
</xsd:complexType>
```

I'm not sure how to give you a test case for this one, but it looks like the last time this worked was release 0.9.0. 

Please let me know if there's anything else I can provide that would help tracking this down.

title: Using zeep in Django with USE_TZ setting causes "can't compare offset-naive and offset-aware datetimes" error
body:
If I use zeep within a Django application that uses sqlite as the backend, and has the USE_TZ setting enabled, zeep throws a timezone offset-related error. 

The datetime coming back from sqlite is timezone-aware, but the datetime stored in `offset` is timezone-naive because [datetime.utcnow() is timezone-naive](https://docs.python.org/2/library/datetime.html#datetime.datetime.utcnow). 

Here's the stack trace:

```
Traceback (most recent call last):
<elided>
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/site-packages/zeep/client.py", line 45, in __init__
    self.wsdl = Document(wsdl, self.transport)
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/site-packages/zeep/wsdl/wsdl.py", line 60, in __init__
    document = self._load_content(location)
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/site-packages/zeep/wsdl/wsdl.py", line 117, in _load_content
    location, self.transport, self._parser_context, self.location)
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/site-packages/zeep/parser.py", line 44, in load_external
    response = transport.load(url)
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/site-packages/zeep/transports.py", line 24, in load
    response = self.cache.get(url)
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/site-packages/zeep/cache.py", line 71, in get
    if not self._timeout or created > offset:
TypeError: can't compare offset-naive and offset-aware datetimes
```

title: KeyError: No element 'BOERequestHeader' in namespace
body:

The behavior has improved since issue #79 was resolved (I think the parsing gets farther along), but it appears there are still some remaining issues.

To be clear, this result is obtained using the master branch after patch #87 was applied.
## expected results
- zeep parses the wsdl and produces an interface
## actual results
- zeep throws KeyError

``` python
KeyError: "No element 'BOERequestHeader' in namespace http://www.boe.ca.gov/ws/002. Available elements are: {http://www.boe.ca.gov/ws/002}EchoResponse"
```
## steps to reproduce
1. Extract the attached zipfile in a directory
   - [wsdl.zip](https://github.com/mvantellingen/python-zeep/files/324175/wsdl.zip)
2. cd to that directory
3. try to parse the wsdl


title: Don't use the wrong SOAPAction
body:
I think that commit 2807eeedd375e59cabe6b4af8312eb7c6a0c86a6 is wrong (or, at least: it broke my code :)).
The WSDL I am talking to is this one:
http://e-port.almaviva.it/integration-web/services/NotificheDiCaricoImplPort?wsdl

For example, this is an excerpt of "annullaNotificaDiCarico":

```
<wsdl:operation name="annullaNotificaDiCarico">
  <soap:operation soapAction="" style="document"/>
  ....
</wsdl:operation>
```

Note that soapAction is explicitly set to "": before the offending commit, everything worked fine. Now, zeep automatically changes the SOAPAction header to "annullaNotificaDiCarico", and the web service emits an error:

```
Fault: The given SOAPAction annullaNotificaDiCarico does not match an operation.
```

have a few rounds of trial, and found that the <xs:choice minOccurs="0"> items has to be included, otherwise it will fail. Therefore the following code works:

```
motype = 'EPSMultiSC@http://schemas.example.com/ma/HSS/'
moid = {'imsi': imsi}
moattr = {'CreateEPSMultiSC': {'imsi': imsi, 'msisdn': msisdn, 'epsProfileId': 'ExampleProfile', 'epsExtendedAccessRestriction': '32', 'commonMsisdn': msisdn}}
response = soapclient.service.Create(motype, moid, moattr, _soapheader = sessionid)
```

But in fact those items ("epsAccessRestriction" or "epsExtendedAccessRestriction", "epsCommonMsisdn" or "commonMsisdn") are optional, user should be able to choose to include them or not in the request.

WSDL & XSD: 
[eps_wsdl_xsd.zip](https://github.com/mvantellingen/python-zeep/files/313316/eps_wsdl_xsd.zip)

title: Cannot set sub-type in sequence
body:
Using sub-types (complex extensions) within a sequence results in a couple of errors:
- Sequences assume that the input is a mapping
- xs:type is not written for sequence elements

Here is a gist with a monkey patch that resolves these issues (it doesn't seem to introduce new issues, but I haven't tested it very exhaustively): https://gist.github.com/nicholjy/436ae857c30ae6a5bf8cafdeb7921ca3

I'm traveling now, but I should have time in a week or so to submit a pull request with tests.
##### Repro:

```
from lxml import etree
from zeep import xsd

node = etree.fromstring("""
    <?xml version="1.0"?>
    <schema
            xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"
            xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"
            xmlns:tns="http://tests.python-zeep.org/"
            elementFormDefault="qualified"
            targetNamespace="http://tests.python-zeep.org/">
      <complexType name="BaseType" abstract="true">
        <sequence>
          <element name="name" type="xsd:string" minOccurs="0"/>
        </sequence>
      </complexType>
      <complexType name="SubType1">
        <complexContent>
          <extension base="tns:BaseType">
            <attribute name="attr_1" type="xsd:string"/>
          </extension>
        </complexContent>
      </complexType>
      <complexType name="PolySequenceType">
        <sequence>
          <element name="item" type="tns:BaseType" maxOccurs="unbounded" minOccurs="0"/>
        </sequence>
      </complexType>
      <element name="Seq" type="tns:PolySequenceType"/>
    </schema>
    """.strip())

schema = xsd.Schema(node)
seq = schema.get_type('ns0:PolySequenceType')
sub_type = schema.get_type('ns0:SubType1')
value = seq(item=[sub_type(attr_1="test", name="name")])

node = etree.Element('document')
seq.render(node, value)
print(etree.tostring(node))
```

title: Usage of _soapheader for adding sessionId in SOAP header
body:
I was trying to perform a simple login and logout with Zeep, the login is successful but the logout is not. I think I got a problem with the SOAP header. When login, I don't need to include a header with SessionId, but for logout I will need to provide the sessionid for the logout, where I have to include SessionId in my SOAP header.

I've read the [issue 33](https://github.com/mvantellingen/python-zeep/issues/33) and tried to use _soapheader to include my header. However I can't set value for the SessionId.

```
response = client.service.Login(username, password)
sid = response.sessionId
request = client.service._binding.create_message('Logout', sid, _soapheader={'SessionId':'123'})
print 'Request is: '
print(etree.tostring(request, pretty_print=True))
```

The above code gives a header with empty SessionId: (pieces of the response )

```
...
  <soap-env:Header>
    <ns0:SessionId></ns0:SessionId>
  </sopa-env:Header>
  <soap-env:Body>
    <ns0:Logout>
      <ns0:sessionId>f8836958a9724e1a8da19439d94a428f</ns0:sessionId>
    </ns:0:Logout>
  </soap-env:Body>
...
```

The soap body part are correct, but the header missing the SessionId value

A correct one should look like:

```
...
  <soap-env:Header>
    <ns0:SessionId>f8836958a9724e1a8da19439d94a428f</ns0:SessionId>
  </sopa-env:Header>
  <soap-env:Body>
    <ns0:Logout>
      <ns0:sessionId>f8836958a9724e1a8da19439d94a428f</ns0:sessionId>
    </ns:0:Logout>
  </soap-env:Body>
...
```

Am I not using "_soapheader in a correct way"? Thanks in advance.

Attached wsdl & xsd for reference
[wsdl_xsd.zip](https://github.com/mvantellingen/python-zeep/files/309086/wsdl_xsd.zip)

title: Error parsing xsd - dependency handling
body:
Hi there

first of all thanks a lot for this great project!

It looks like the xsd parser expects sequential order of dependencies inside the xsd file, which isn't the case in my xsd i'm forced to use. if i reorder it manually it works like expected. 

example xsd given:

``` xml
<xs:schema xmlns="http://www.swisscom.com/wsg/bb/v29" xmlns:xs="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema" targetNamespace="http://www.swisscom.com/wsg/bb/v29" elementFormDefault="qualified" attributeFormDefault="unqualified">
    <xs:annotation>
        <xs:documentation>Common types for WSG </xs:documentation>
    </xs:annotation>
    <!-- ********************************************* -->
    <!--             SIMPLE TYPES                      -->
    <!-- ********************************************* -->
    <!-- accessSpeedProfileNrType -->
    <xs:simpleType name="accessSpeedProfileNrType">
        <xs:annotation>
            <xs:documentation>[LOV-ID: 1010] An access speed profile number.</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
        <xs:restriction base="speedProfileNrType"/>
    </xs:simpleType>
    <!-- speedProfileNrType -->
    <xs:simpleType name="speedProfileNrType">
        <xs:annotation>
            <xs:documentation>[LOV-ID: 1010] A speed profile number.</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
        <xs:restriction base="lovType"/>
    </xs:simpleType>
    <!-- lovType -->
    <xs:simpleType name="lovType">
        <xs:annotation>
            <xs:documentation>The abstract LOV base type.</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
        <xs:restriction base="xs:int">
            <xs:totalDigits value="3"/>
        </xs:restriction>
    </xs:simpleType>
</xs:schema>
```

This fails in **xsd/schema.py** with:

```
KeyError: "No such type: '{http://www.swisscom.com/wsg/bb/v29}speedProfileNrType' (Only have )"
```

if i reorder it like this:

``` xml
<xs:schema xmlns="http://www.swisscom.com/wsg/bb/v29" xmlns:xs="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema" targetNamespace="http://www.swisscom.com/wsg/bb/v29" elementFormDefault="qualified" attributeFormDefault="unqualified">
    <xs:annotation>
        <xs:documentation>Common types for WSG </xs:documentation>
    </xs:annotation>
    <!-- ********************************************* -->
    <!--             SIMPLE TYPES                      -->
    <!-- ********************************************* -->
    <!-- lovType -->
    <xs:simpleType name="lovType">
        <xs:annotation>
            <xs:documentation>The abstract LOV base type.</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
        <xs:restriction base="xs:int">
            <xs:totalDigits value="3"/>
        </xs:restriction>
    </xs:simpleType>
    <!-- speedProfileNrType -->
    <xs:simpleType name="speedProfileNrType">
        <xs:annotation>
            <xs:documentation>[LOV-ID: 1010] A speed profile number.</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
        <xs:restriction base="lovType"/>
    </xs:simpleType>
    <!-- accessSpeedProfileNrType -->
    <xs:simpleType name="accessSpeedProfileNrType">
        <xs:annotation>
            <xs:documentation>[LOV-ID: 1010] An access speed profile number.</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
        <xs:restriction base="speedProfileNrType"/>
    </xs:simpleType>
</xs:schema>
```

it works like expected. 

**additional info:** 
- the wsdl loads with SoapUI and suds like expected.
- the same error also appears when a complexType refers to a simpleType before it is defined inside the xsd
- tested with the current master.zip installed i a virtualenv with python3.5

title: regression with getting types
body:
before commit b04dba2ce3295d635e13d315001e94e157e976b3 this was working ok:

``` python
client = Client('http://destservices.touricoholidays.com/DestinationsService.svc?wsdl')
type = client.get_type('ns1:Destination')
```

after this error is raised:

```
work/room/room/tourico/api.py:24: in __init__
    self.service_arg_type = self.client.get_type(method_arg_name)
/envs/room/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/zeep/client.py:99: in get_type
    return self.wsdl.schema.get_type(name)
/envs/room/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/zeep/xsd/schema.py:111: in get_type
    name = self._create_qname(name)
/envs/room/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/zeep/xsd/schema.py:162: in _create_qname
    return etree.QName(name)
src/lxml/lxml.etree.pyx:1831: in lxml.etree.QName.__init__ (src/lxml/lxml.etree.c:61175)
    ???
src/lxml/apihelpers.pxi:1626: in lxml.etree._tagValidOrRaise (src/lxml/lxml.etree.c:32662)
    ???
E   ValueError: Invalid tag name u'ns1:Destination'
```

after little investigation I've found that the `client.wsdl.schema._prefix_map` contained this:
`{'ns0': 'http://touricoholidays.com/WSDestinations/2008/08/Contracts/Imports', 'ns1': 'http://touricoholidays.com/WSDestinations/2008/08/DataContracts', 'ns2': 'http://schemas.microsoft.com/2003/10/Serialization/'}
`

after the commit it's empty.

```
/envs/rooms/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/zeep/xsd/elements.py:112: in parse
    return self.type.parse_xmlelement(value)
_ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ 

self = <zeep.xsd.types.Hotel object at 0x7f30672258d0>
xmlelement = <Element {http://touricoholidays.com/WSDestinations/2008/08/DataContracts}Hotel at 0x7f30676e1488>

    def parse_xmlelement(self, xmlelement):
        instance = self()
        fields = self.properties()
        if not fields:
            return instance

        elements = xmlelement.getchildren()
        attributes = xmlelement.attrib
        if not elements and not attributes:
            return

        fields_map = {f.name: f for f in fields if isinstance(f, Attribute)}
        for key, value in attributes.items():
            field = fields_map.get(key)
            if not field:
                continue
            value = field.parse(value)
            setattr(instance, key, value)

        fields = iter(f for f in fields if not isinstance(f, Attribute))
>       field = next(fields)
E       StopIteration

/envs/rooms/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/zeep/xsd/types.py:197: StopIteration
```

This seems to fix it here https://github.com/mvantellingen/python-zeep/blob/master/src/zeep/xsd/types.py#L197:

``` python
field = next(fields, None)
if not field:
    return instance
```

I can't find a right place to do this with tests, sorry.

title: 'list' object has no attribute 'min_occurs'
body:
I am just about positive that this is not a problem with zeep, just thought I might reach out for help. Just a note, I am trying to wrap a web service which is defined by a WSDL which comes from a company which seems to be known (at least in my circles) for not following standards (or making up their own as they go).

So I need to ask first if it's supported to use a WSDL from the local filesystem instead of from a URL? I didn't see it mentioned in the documentation, but figured I'd give it a try anyway. My code looks like this:

``` python
import zeep

client = zeep.Client("./proprietary.wsdl")
```

At this point I get this traceback:

```
Traceback (most recent call last):

  File "/home/ilovetux/anaconda3/lib/python3.5/site-packages/zeep/xsd/visitor.py", line 94, in visit_schema

  File "/home/ilovetux/anaconda3/lib/python3.5/site-packages/zeep/xsd/visitor.py", line 41, in process
    result = visit_func(self, node, parent)
  File "/home/ilovetux/anaconda3/lib/python3.5/site-packages/zeep/xsd/visitor.py", line 157, in visit_include
    return self.visit_schema(schema_node)
  File "/home/ilovetux/anaconda3/lib/python3.5/site-packages/zeep/xsd/visitor.py", line 94, in visit_schema
    self.process(node, parent=parent)
  File "/home/ilovetux/anaconda3/lib/python3.5/site-packages/zeep/xsd/visitor.py", line 41, in process
    result = visit_func(self, node, parent)
  File "/home/ilovetux/anaconda3/lib/python3.5/site-packages/zeep/xsd/visitor.py", line 209, in visit_element

    elm.min_occurs = 0
AttributeError: 'list' object has no attribute 'min_occurs'
```

Honestly, I was expecting to get a connection error or something similar, for which I might simply offer a pull-request, but this seems like it's a problem with the actual WSDL.

Trying to debug the situation, I changed [this method](https://github.com/mvantellingen/python-zeep/blob/master/src/zeep/xsd/visitor.py#L715) to read as follows:

``` python
    def visit_choice(self, node, parent):
        """
            <choice
              id = ID
              maxOccurs= (nonNegativeInteger | unbounded) : 1
              minOccurs= nonNegativeInteger : 1
              {any attributes with non-schema Namespace}...>
            Content: (annotation?, (element | group | choice | sequence | any)*)
            </choice>
        """
        # There should be only max nodes, first node (annotation) is irrelevant
        children = node.getchildren()
        if children[0].tag == tags.annotation:
            children.pop(0)

        choices = []
        for child in children:
            elm = self.process(child, node)
            try:
                elm.min_occurs = 0
            except:
                print(etree.tostring(child, pretty_print=True).decode("utf-8"))
                raise
            choices.append(elm)
        return xsd_elements.Choice(choices)
```

And in addition to the above traceback I got this (I'm not sure about license, so I took out anything identifying):

``` xml
<xsd:sequence xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema" xmlns:ns1="http://www.proprietary.com/URI">
    <xsd:element name="UniqueElement-1" type="xsd:string"/>
    <xsd:element name="UniqueElement-2" type="xsd:string"/>

    <xsd:element name="UniqueElement-8" type="ns1:CustomType-3" minOccurs="0" maxOccurs="unbounded"/>
    <xsd:element name="UniqueElement-9" type="ns1:CustomType-4" minOccurs="0" maxOccurs="1"/>
    <xsd:element name="UniqueElement-10" type="ns1:CustomType-5" minOccurs="0" maxOccurs="unbounded"/>
    <xsd:element name="UniqueElement-11" type="ns1:CustomType-6" minOccurs="0" maxOccurs="unbounded"/>
</xsd:sequence>
```

To my untrained eye, it looks ok, but it's too late tonight for me to go pouring over the WSDL/XSD spec. Is the problem amazingly obvious and I'm just missing it?

title: org.xml.sax.SAXException: None is not a legal value
body:
I am using zeep 0.7.0.dev0. The following

``` python
from zeep import Client
from zeep.transports import Transport
from zeep.cache import SqliteCache

cache=SqliteCache(persistent=False, timeout=60)

transport = Transport(cache=cache,verify=False)
wsdl='https://webservices.netsuite.com/wsdl/v2016_1_0/netsuite.wsdl'
client=Client(wsdl,transport=transport)

Passport=client.get_type('ns0:Passport')

RecordRef=client.get_type('ns0:RecordRef')

myrole=RecordRef(internalId='1111')

passport=Passport(account='123456',
                       email='obviously@fake.email',
                       password='password',
                       role=myrole
                       )

response=client.service.login(passport)
```

```
zeep.exceptions.Fault: org.xml.sax.SAXException: None is not a legal value for {urn:types.core_2016_1.platform.webservices.netsuite.com}RecordType
```

``` python
                                <ns0:email>obviously@fake.email</ns0:email>
                                <ns0:password>password</ns0:password>
                                <ns0:account>123456</ns0:account>
                                <ns0:role internalId="1111" {0}/>
                        </ns2:passport>
                </ns2:login>
        </soap-env:Body>
</soap-env:Envelope>""".format(attrs)

r=requests.post("https://webservices.netsuite.com/services/NetSuitePort_2016_1",
                headers=headers,
                data=payload,
                verify=False)
print(r.text)
```

title: Some Types are note decoded correctly
body:
When I try to call a service provided by [this](http://almdemo.polarion.com/polarion/ws/services/TrackerWebService?wsdl) WSDL, specifically the `getCustomField`, the Python objects seem to be of the type "None".

I just printed the return value, which looks like this:

```
{   'key': None,
    'parentItemURI': 'subterra:data-service:objects:/default/linux${WorkItem}LI-321',
    'value': None}
```

For debugging purpose I caught the packets send by the server with WireShark:

```
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<soapenv:Envelope xmlns:soapenv="http://schemas.xmlsoap.org/soap/envelope/" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance">
  <soapenv:Body>
    <getCustomFieldResponse xmlns="http://ws.polarion.com/TrackerWebService-impl">
      <getCustomFieldReturn>
        <ns1:parentItemURI xmlns:ns1="http://ws.polarion.com/TrackerWebService-types">subterra:data-service:objects:/default/linux${WorkItem}LI-321</ns1:parentItemURI>
        <ns2:key xmlns:ns2="http://ws.polarion.com/TrackerWebService-types">solution</ns2:key>
        <ns3:value xmlns:ns3="http://ws.polarion.com/TrackerWebService-types" xmlns:ns4="http://ws.polarion.com/types" xsi:type="ns4:Text">
          <ns4:type xsi:type="xsd:string">text/html</ns4:type>
          <ns4:content xsi:type="xsd:string">Test Solution </ns4:content>
          <ns4:contentLossy xsi:type="xsd:boolean">false</ns4:contentLossy>
        </ns3:value>
      </getCustomFieldReturn>
    </getCustomFieldResponse>
  </soapenv:Body>
</soapenv:Envelope>
```

I can't see any problems with the response, except that the server opens different namespaces for the same namespace. At least for the "key" I would expect that zeep returns the string without hassle.
